rounds.comments: (Alex: Here's a tribute to you, Bill...)

clues.text: R.J. Reynolds dropped this drawn character after drawing complaints it drew kids to cigarettes
From its start in 1993, this Steven Bochco show has been attacked by the Christian Family Network
In July 1997 the National Federation for the Blind urged a halt to a live-action version of this cartoon
A 1989 protest by a Michigan housewife against this Fox sitcom only boosted its popularity
Ira Zimmerman led a protest of the mocking of Michael Palin's stuttering in this 1988 film
In her book "My Turn", she points out that Eleanor Roosevelt was criticized for ordering new china, too
She donated the net proceeds of her dog Millie's book to her Foundation for Family Literacy
First Lady seen here when she was a young girl:
This Texas-born conservationist headed the First Lady's Committee for A More Beautiful Capital
She started wearing those famous bangs while living in the Panama Canal Zone with her military husband
He was born in the capital Nov. 25, 1960, 17 days after his dad was elected president
Lisa Halaby, born in D.C. in 1951, married King Hussein & became Queen Noor of this country
He was born in Washington on Jan. 1, 1895 & became the FBI's director at 29
This TV journalist, who longed for parenthood, is the 10th child of a Chinese diplomat
Washington-born "Crossfire" host & 1996 presidential candidate
A spare on a car, or an extra person on a double date
On the fifth day God created these, like the one that swallowed Jonah
On this date in 1776 the Declaration of Independence was mailed to towns across the colonies
A fifth of liquor is one-fifth of this measure
In 1967 they rose to the Top 10 singing "Up, Up And Away In My Beautiful Balloon"
In "Paper Lion" George Plimpton reported on his attempt to play this sport
A 1996 history of this substance includes sections on bakelite, polyethylene & cellophane
Frank McCourt put his mother's name in the title of this bestselling memoir
The title of this 1994 book about group differences in intelligence refers to a shape on a graph
Song that's the title of Robert Dallek's book on "The Making and Unmaking of American Presidents"
This team's logo is on champagne bottles commemorating the opening of Jack Kent Cooke Stadium
On May 15, 1997 the NBA's Washington Bullets took this name
Ron Wilson, the former head coach of the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim, now coaches this team
The D.C. United plays this sport outside while the Warthogs play it indoors
Before moving, this baseball team was called, "First in War, First in Peace & Last in the American League"

rounds.comments: (Alex: These clues all have to do with people who have the same name as an animal; a perfect example, of course, is Wolf Blitzer; Blitzer, as we all know, is one of Santa Claus' reindeer!)

clues.text: In 1883 he opened his Wild West Show in Omaha, Nebraska
In 1997 he broke Jack Nicklaus' 32-year-old Masters record of 17 under par
In the victory column, this Alabamian has 4 more than Pop Warner
On "Another Saturday Night" you'll find him "Sitting" on a "Peace Train" until "Morning Has Broken"
This "Good Morning, Vietnam" star once studied drama with John Houseman
In 1993 he was "In the Line of Fire" as Secret Service agent Frank Horrigan
This star of "Grumpy Old Men" played a grumpy Supreme Court justice in "First Monday in October"
Laurence Harvey & Frank Sinatra starred in this 1962 political thriller based on a novel by Richard Condon
In "All the President's Men", Hal Holbrook played this informer whose true identity is still a mystery
This British actor, JFK's brother-in-law, played a U.S. senator in "Advise and Consent"
He was nicknamed "Red" as a child, but you know him better as "Silent Cal"
As a youth, this Georgian was nicknamed "Hot", short for "Hot Shot"
William McKinley was known as the "Idol of" this Buckeye state, his birthplace
Men who slandered his wife Rachel found out quickly why he was called the "Duel Fighter"
This "Bachelor President" was affectionately nicknamed "Old Buck"
Once meaning "lacking religious beliefs", it now means cheating on your spouse
It once meant "an insult", so you'd be adding insult to...insult
Now it's a den in which you'd find an animal lion around; a long time ago, it was "a coach"
It was a tavern, or a clump of ivy hung on a pub; today it's a small shrub, or an ex-president
Henry, Jane, Peter or Bridget might tell you that this 4-letter word once meant "foolish"
An 1873 law requires that this Latin motto appear on one side of every U.S. coin
This agency, the GAO, advises Congress on the use of public funds
An amendment becomes part of the Constitution after this many states have ratified it
This Treasury Department agency, the ATF, investigates hitmen & mad bombers
clues.response: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms

clues.text: Most presidential libraries are controlled by this agency which maintains our government records
In April 1994 this Charles replaced Charles Kuralt on CBS News Sunday Morning
The Crystal Cathedral is the setting of this reverend's "Hour of Power"
His name no longer appears in the title of ABC's "This Week"
This show is based in Washington, D.C where host Tim Russert is NBC's bureau chief
Now appearing together on CNN, these 2 journalists first teamed up for a newspaper column in 1963

rounds.text: The Holy Roman Empire from 800 to 1806 was the first; the German empire from 1871 to 1918 was the second
